Saccharomyces cerevisiae, also known as baker’s yeast, is a single-celled eukaryote that can make <math alttext="A T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> both aerobically and anaerobically. To obtain a readily accessible form of chemical energy for cellular activities, many strains of yeast convert glucose into ethyl alcohol and carbon dioxide.

Researchers conducted an experiment to determine the effect of temperature on the rate of glucose conversion to ethyl alcohol and carbon dioxide. They added an equal mass of yeast cells to equal volumes of a glucose solution in a series of sealed test tubes. Groups of tubes were incubated at temperatures ranging from <math alttext="28 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>28°C</mtext></math> to <math alttext="40 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>40</mtext><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></math>, the optimal range for yeast growth. The researchers measured carbon dioxide production in the tubes.

(a) Describe the importance of fermentation to eukaryotic cells such as yeast.

Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored.

Saccharomyces cerevisiae, also known as baker’s yeast, is a single-celled eukaryote that can make <math alttext="A T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> both aerobically and anaerobically. To obtain a readily accessible form of chemical energy for cellular activities, many strains of yeast convert glucose into ethyl alcohol and carbon dioxide.

Researchers conducted an experiment to determine the effect of temperature on the rate of glucose conversion to ethyl alcohol and carbon dioxide. They added an equal mass of yeast cells to equal volumes of a glucose solution in a series of sealed test tubes. Groups of tubes were incubated at temperatures ranging from <math alttext="28 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>28°C</mtext></math> to <math alttext="40 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>40</mtext><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></math>, the optimal range for yeast growth. The researchers measured carbon dioxide production in the tubes.

(a) Describe the importance of fermentation to eukaryotic cells such as yeast.
(b) Identify the independent variable in the experiment.

(c) Predict the relative rates of glucose breakdown at <math alttext="4 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>4°C</mtext></math> AND at <math alttext="56 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>56°C</mtext></math> compared with the rate at <math alttext="37 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>37°C</mtext></math>.
(d) Provide reasoning to support your prediction in part (c).
